title: Colon tops White Pigeon to clinch playoff berth
text: Colon tops White Pigeon to clinch playoff berth Colon picks up 16-8 win Comment Posted Oct. 23, 2015 at 11:48 PM Colon punched their ticket for the playoffs with a 16-8 win over White Pigeon Friday night. “Wow, what a feeling,” Colon coach Richard Roth said. “Our boys played a great game. We got a little excited in the fourth, but settled down and controlled the line of scrimmage against a very physical team. With the score knotted 8-8 midway through the third quarter, Daniel Alva scored on a 15-yard run. Alva added the two conversion. The Magi took a 8-0 lead at 9:18 of the first quarter on a 15-yard scoring run by Kaleb Bohm and the two-point conversion by Gabe Keely. The Chiefs tied the game at 9:27 of the second quarter on a 3-yard run by Hunter Rummler. Sabastian Castro scored for the two-point conversion. On the night Colon had 223 yards of rushing, led by Bohm with 92 yards on eight carries. Alva added 54 yards on 13 attempts and Keely had 48-yards on 12 totes. Through the air, Alva was 5-of-11 for 66-yards. Brett Prell was the leading receiver, catching three passes for 50-yards. Defensively, the Magi were led by Jacob Cornett with 13 total tackles, one forced fumble and a fumble recovery. Chris Frame had eight tackles and Chase Thrams had seven tackles, including a sack. Logan Vaughn had fumble recovery and a interception. For the Chiefs, Rummler ran for 126-yards on 25 carries. Castro added 50-yards on seven carries. Jacob Black was 5-of-15 in the air for 34-yards. Galvin Kopf led the receiving with two catches for 18-yards. Rummler was White Pigeon’s leading tackler with 11. He also forced a fumble and picked off a pass. Castro added eight tackles and Jared Mroz had seven. Vicksburg 31, Three Rivers 16 Vicksburg ended their season at 7-2, with a 31-16 win over Three Rivers. The Bulldogs defense shut down the Three Rivers ground game, holding the cats to a mere 29. Vicksburg led 8-0 after the first quarter. The Cats Riley Seifert put Three Rivers on the board with a 20-yard field goal at the beginning of the second quarter. Vicksburg took a 14-3 lead on a Nick Wallace three yard run. With just under three minutes left in the half, Adam Reed scrambled his way into the end zone for the score. The lone scoring in the third quarter came to the Bulldogs Joe Brady, who split the uprights for 29-yard field goal. Vicksburg upped their lead to start the fourth quarter on 13-yard run by Brandon Lovell. Reed hit Chad Sage on a 48-yard scoring strike and with the point after by Seifert trailed 24-16. The Bulldogs iced the with 1:58 left in the game on a two-yard run by Lovell. Page 2 of 2 - Three Rivers was led in rushing by Reed, who gained just 18-yards on 10 carries. Through the air reed was 21-0f-29 for 230 yards. Sage was the leading receiver with 125-yards on nine catches, followed by Tanner Blyly with four catches for 54 yards and Alex Minger with one reception for 27. Tyler Moore led the Cats defense with 10 total tackles, while Traven VanOss had seven. Constantine 21, Hartford 6 Constantine kept their playoff hopes alive, while dimming Hartford’s with a 21-6 win Friday night. The Falcons took a 7-0 lead on a 68-yard run by Matt Hasbrouck. Tristian Butler added the extra point. Constantine took a 14-0 lead into the brake after Anthony Evilsizor scored on a one-yard plunge. Butler again added the point after. Eric Petoskey added an insurance score on a 12-yard gallup. Hartford scored their lone points in the fourth quarter. Hasbrouck led the Falcons ground attack with 106-yards on seven carries, Petoskey was five yards shy of the century mark on 10 attempts. Evilsizor added 74-yards on eight carries. The Falcons defense held the Indians to just 54-yards rushing and 31-yards through the air. Butler was the leading tackler with 11 total tackles, followed by Travis Long with nine including one sack. Long also had a fumble recovery and Evilsizor had a interception.
